Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Expanding Rights Claims Before Supranational Courts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scholarship has demonstrated the challenges of using legal institutions to expand rights claims; implementation is difficult and often requires continuous attention by mobilized groups. Yet around the world organizations turn to supranational courts to make claims. Despite the increasing number of studies on human rights courts and how people and organizations mobilize law, we lack a comparative study that explains when and how groups concerned with employment conditions turn to international human rights courts, and what they expect to gain, given difficulties of the translation of claims into law and into practice. The involvement of supranational courts is recent in the employment policy domain; most of the time claims have been left to national courts. This research will generate both quantitative data on the developing case law on labor issues at the European Court of Human Rights and qualitative analyses of two cases of mobilization to assess the efforts concerning employment. The project will assess the hypothesis that organizations turn to courts in particular fields where no other institution is available. In doing so, the project will contribute to understanding of the interplay of institutions in significant policy domains.

This research will produce, analyze, and disseminate the first comprehensive database on labor cases at the European Court of Human Rights, a significant supranational institution yet one that is not well-understood. The database will provide information concerning who mobilizes, what the effects of mobilization are in terms of court outcomes and group claiming, and the expansion of understandings of rights. This cross-national and longitudinal database will be pivotal for researchers seeking to analyze the Court's evolving approach. This timely research will contribute to multiple fields of study and provide social benefits by investigating the consequences of using international human rights law.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project centers on labor activism and human rights. After decades of mistrust  against human rights and judicial strategies, activists in Europe have started claiming labor rights as human rights. Analyzing the mobilization efforts of labor activists at the European Court of Human
rights (ECtHR, or the Court), this research aims to understand whether and how human rights frameworks become resources for labor activists. This project has generated two types of original data: a quantitative database on the labor cases brought before the ECtHR (1960-2014), and a
qualitative study of two cases of grassroots labor activism in Turkey and the UK. The National Science Foundation has supported the qualitative study, which consisted of 10 months of fieldwork in these two countries.


The quantiative data (n=1,600) shows that labor activists in Europe are increasingly turning to the ECtHR, and that the Court has become more responsive to these cases, after years of shunning labor cases. Labor activists litigate a variety of cases, from workers’ health and safety to workplace surveillance, at the Court. The ECtHR delivered some landmark cases specifically in the area of trade union rights, including, but not limited to, rights to collective bargaining and to strike. Thus, the fieldwork studies on grassroots activism focused on these rights in practice.


The fieldwork in Turkey and the UK primarily consisted of interviews, participant observation, and collecting written documents of activism. I conducted over 70 interviews with academics, who contribute to the litigation process, as well as labor activists and lawyers from grassroots labor groups, trade unions, legal advocacy groups, human rights organizations, pro-labor law firms, and labor organizations. I also conducted participant observation in meetings, workshops, seminars, campaigns, and demonstrations organized by the above mentined groups.


Four major findings resulted from the qualitative study.


First, within a context of shrinking welfare states and declining trade union rights protection in Europe, the ECtHR, as a human rights court, emerged
as one of the few institutional sites left at which organized labor could direct mobilization efforts. Yet, not all labor activists have the same degree of success in utilizing the Court. Domestic factors, such as strength of organized labor and legal advocacy networks, play a significant role in
determining when and how litigation at an international court can become a resource for labor activists.


Second, the UK provides a more hospitable environment for legal mobilization at an international court than Turkey due to several reasons. Notwithstanding the institution of similar neoliberal policies aimed at undermining labor in both countries, organized labor in the UK is relatively stronger than in Turkey. Moreover, the dense network of legal advocacy groups in the UK situate labor activists in a better position to litigate at the ECtHR. Last, the UK has a higher compliance record with the ECtHR rulings than Turkey, which increases the likelihood of mobilization.


Third, despite the more favorable domestic context in the UK for litigating labor rights at the ECtHR, the policy outcomes ensuing the ECtHR cases fail to fulfill the expectations of trade unionists.
